verb.description: Separate or cause to separate into pieces as a result of a blow, shock, or strain.
examples: the rope broke with a loud snap
windows in the street were broken by the blast
the slate fell from my hand and broke in two on the hard floor
break the chocolate into pieces
the new government broke the pattern of growth
his concentration was broken by a sound

verb.description: Fail to observe (a law, regulation, or agreement)
examples: the district attorney says she will prosecute retailers who break the law
a legally binding contract that can only be broken by mutual consent

verb.description: Crush the emotional strength, spirit, or resistance of.
examples: the idea was to better the prisoners, not to break them
the weather broke and thunder rumbled through a leaden sky

verb.description: (of news or a scandal) suddenly become public.
examples: since the news broke I've received thousands of wonderful letters

verb.description: (chiefly of an attacking player or team, or of a military force) make a rush or dash in a particular direction.
examples: the flight broke to the right and formed a defensive circle

noun.description: An interruption of continuity or uniformity.
examples: the magazine has been published without a break since 1950

noun.description: A pause in work or during an activity or event.
examples: I need a break from mental activity
those returning to work after a career break
they take long coffee breaks
he stopped to wait for a break in the traffic
the spectacular vistas occasionally offered by a break in the rainforest

noun.description: An instance of breaking something, or the point where something is broken.
examples: a break in the valve was being repaired

noun.description: A rush or dash in a particular direction, especially by an attacking player or team.
examples: he made a bounce pass for a basket on the break in the second quarter

noun.description: An opportunity or chance, especially one leading to professional success.
examples: he got his break as an entertainer on a TV music hall show

noun.description: A consecutive series of successful shots, scoring a specified number of points.
examples: a break of 83 put him in front for the first time

phrases: we've broken the back of the problem
They broke the back of their task with an opening stand of 111 in only 18 overs.
My belief would be that three or four weeks of intensive work would break the back of it and make sure that people started to think about things differently.
They broke the back of the task by adding 81 runs in 16 overs for the first wicket.
The grants from broke the back of the funding but raising the rest was still a real challenge.
You need sleep, I said, breaking away from him and opening the door.
He broke away abruptly and held her arms so she couldn't move away.
He broke away from Conor and raced into the bushes, fading into the shadows.
I broke away, eyes opening slowly to see what damage had truly been done.
She was too stunned to move for a moment before she broke away from him.
origin: Mid 19th century: perhaps from 16th-century brake cage, later framework, of unknown origin.
